review.title: Measuring Asymmetric Opinions on Online Social Interrelationship with Language and Network Features
review.abstract: Instead of studying the properties of social relationship from an objective view, in this paper, we focus on individuals' subjective and asymmetric opinions on their interrelationships. Inspired by the theories from sociolinguistics, we investigate two individuals' opinions on their interrelationship with their interactive language features. Eliminating the difference of personal language style, we clarify that the asymmetry of interactive language feature values can indicate individuals' asymmetric opinions on their interrelationship. We also discuss how the degree of opinions' asymmetry is related to the individuals' personality traits. Furthermore, to measure the individuals' asymmetric opinions on interrelationship concretely, we develop a novel model synthetizing interactive language and social network features. The experimental results with Enron email dataset provide multiple evidences of the asymmetric opinions on interrelationship, and also verify the effectiveness of the proposed model in measuring the degree of opinions' asymmetry.

metadata.title: Measuring Asymmetric Opinions on Online Social Interrelationship by Synthetizing the Interactive Language and Social Network Features

sections.text: Instead of examining the characteristics of social relationships from an objective point of view, in this paper we focus on the subjective and asymmetrical opinions of individuals about their relationships with each other. Inspired by the theories of sociolinguistics, we examine the opinions of two individuals about their interaction with their interactive language traits. By eliminating the difference in personal language style, we clarify that the asymmetry of interactive language traits can point to the asymmetrical opinions of individuals about their interaction with each other. We also discuss how the degree of asymmetry of opinion relates to the personality traits of the individual. In order to concretely measure the asymmetrical opinions of individuals about interactions, we develop a novel model that models interactive language and social network traits. Experimental results with the Enron e-mail datasets provide several proofs for the asymmetrical opinions about interrelations and also verify the effectiveness of the proposed model of social networking in measuring the asymmetrical grammar of the Grammetry of the Concepted Grammetry of the Grammetry of the Grammetry of the S;

sections.heading: 2.1 Symmetric & Asymmetric Analysis of Signed Social Interrelationships
sections.text: Many early studies on social relationships assume that the properties of correlations are symmetrical. Among these papers are some studies on unsigned relationships, and recently researchers have been paying more attention to the analysis of signed relationships, in which the correlations are labeled to illustrate typical types such as positive and negative. The problem of predicting marginal signs in a social network was first identified by Guha et al. [13]. sections.heading: 3. CHARACTERIZE OPINIONS ON INTERRELATIONSHIP WITH INTERACTIVE LANGUAGE FEATURES
sections.text: In recent studies, when researchers want to measure the strength or type (e.g. positive & negative) of social interaction between two individuals from an objective point of view, they often turn to typical objective characteristics, such as embedding the interrelation or frequency of communication between the participants. Results of such methods are often symmetrical, i.e., independent of the direction of the interrelation. If we assume that the properties of the interrelation are not symmetrical, i.e. different for two directions, it is often caused by the difference in the opinions of the two participants. Therefore, how can we describe the opinions of the individuals about their interaction asymmetrically? Some studies choose two objective characteristics, i.e. the frequency of communication in two directions. Although some objective characteristics can be used asymmetrically, they cannot accurately describe the opinions. Therefore, a more reasonable solution is to measure the opinions about the interrelation to subjective realities.

sections.heading: 3.1 Objective Features for Interrelationship
sections.text: Most popular objective characteristics for measuring social relationships are the embedding of a correlation and the frequency of communication between two participants. Embedding can measure the strength of a correlation with the degree of randomness of the correlation between two participants, i.e. the number of common "friends" in many cases. Embedding is an effective objective characteristic that describes the correlation only with the structure of the social network, but is not designed to be measured directly. Frequency of communication can measure the strength of a correlation with the frequency of certain types of communication between two participants. Among the most commonly used cases are the frequency of phone calls, emails and mutual comments on social media. Frequency of communication is not an absolute objective characteristic, because it is actually a type of behavior of the participants and a subjective decision. Although the subjective characteristic of communication frequency leads to the correlation mirroring of communication, it can only reflect opinions in a channel way.

sections.heading: 3.2 Sociolinguistics and Subjective Features
sections.text: Subjective characteristics are the characteristics that can reveal the subjective opinion of the participants about their interactions. In sociolinguistics, the theory of communicative action [14] is proposed to reconstruct the concept of the relationship to the communicative act, instead of objective terms. And the linguistic structures of communication can be used to establish a normative understanding of social relations. Sapir-Whorf hypothesis [24] also assumes that the semantic structure of language with forms or boundaries is the way in which a speaker occupies the world, including social relations. In communication, the choice of words will always depend heavily on their subjective views about their interaction with others. These theories inspire us to form the opinion about an interrelation between languages.

sections.heading: 3.3 Distinguish the Asymmetry of Opinions from the Asymmetry of Language Habits
sections.text: Although the interactive language style of the individual is closely related to his views on his personal relationships, it is inaccurate to directly understand opinions based on the original interactive language characteristics (in the understanding of natural language, the meaning of language is always determined not only by the content, but also by the context).The context of interactive language is very complex, including the language habits of the speaker, the opportunity for dialogue, sentences in the same discourse, etc. In this work, we focus on how to better understand one's own opinion in relation to the others. Suppose A is a very negative person, and he always speaks to person B with a negative polarity score. But we also know that A speaks to each person very negatively and he speaks to B most kindly in relation to the others. In this case, if we want to properly measure the opinion of A in relation to his relationship with B, we use the polarity of the language that I use relative to A in relation to the original language.

sections.heading: 5.5 The Role of Personality Traits
sections.text: In this experiment, we further tried to investigate possible latent reasons for the asymmetry of opinions in relation to social relationships. We focus on the personality traits of the individual. Here, we look at two types of personality traits: the positive degree and the flexible degree of personality. An individual with a higher positive degree means that he adopts a more positive attitude in social relationships, and a higher flexible degree means that his social behaviour is more changeable rather than adhering to a fixed style. We also assumed that the positive degree of an individual can be measured by his linguistic characteristics, i.e. a higher positive degree can be indicated by higher values of frequency, length, quality and sensation. We also assumed that the flexible degree can be measured by the standard deviation of his linguistic characteristics, i.e., a higher flexible degree can be indicated by greater deviation of the linguistic characteristics. sections.heading: 6. EXPERIMENTS OF MEASURING ASYMMETRIC OPINIONS ON INTERRELATIONSHIP
sections.text: In this experiment, we evaluate the proposed model's ability to measure the bidirectional degrees of asymmetric opinions of individuals about their relationships. We describe the data used and the basic truths based on the Enron e-mail data set, and then present the experimental results to compare the performance of the proposed synthesized model and the performance of individual feature models.

sections.text: Data Setting: For this experiment, in the previous filtered set containing 1078 interrelationships between 647 individuals, we obtained the organizational hierarchy of 232 Enron employees provided by Apoorv Agarwal [2]. With this set of data, we can determine the superior subordinate relationships between individuals. Finally, 70 pairs of the superior subordinate relationships are manually exploited, consisting of 80 nodes and 140 directed edges. Therefore, the asymmetry of opinions can be illustrated by the difference in the thickness of the two edges between the node pairs. Figure 4 illustrates the visualization of four interactive linguistic characteristics each. Another interesting observation is that the degree of asymmetry between the "distant" individual pairs, i.e. the pairs far from the center of the node communities, seems to be more significant.

sections.heading: 7. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: In this work, we investigated and measured the asymmetry of individuals "opinions about social interactions using interactive language traits. According to sociolinguistic theories, we used four key language traits to represent their own interactive language style, including frequency, length, quality, and sentiment.As a case study, we used these traits to examine individuals" opinions about interactions with their email content in the Enron dataset. Experimental results showed that the asymmetry of individual language styles is a common effect of the asymmetry of their opinions and the asymmetry of their language habits. We also found that individuals "personality traits can be a latent cause of their asymmetric opinions about interactions: positive and flexible personality can alleviate the asymmetry of opinions about interactions. We further developed a model that synthesized interactive language and social network traits to jointly measure the concrete degree of asymmetric opinions about social interactions.
